data.title: 23 famous people that Derbyshire has given to the world
data.meta_description: Derbyshire has produced a galaxy of stars doing us proud
data.text:
Plenty of well-known personalities from public life began their days in Derbyshire and quite a few remain here to this day.

Some are easily identifiable as having their roots in the county while others might come as a surprise to Derbyshire Live readers.

From TV to cycling and fashion design to politics and film, Derbyshire has produced plenty of talent.

We even have our own 007…

Here is our latest list of public figures, sports stars and celebrities with Derbyshire roots who are still doing Derbyshire proud.

Tess Daly

The Strictly Come Dancing co-host grew up in the village of Birch Vale near New Mills in North Derbyshire.

Daly’s initial fame came as a model whose work included an appearance in the video to Duran Duran hit Notorious.

Following a move into TV Daly’s big break came in 2004 when she joined Strictly as Bruce Forsyth’s co-presenter.

Daly, who has also written two novels, is married to TV presenter and DJ Vernon Kay.

Sat Bains

The Derby-born and educated chef is best known for being chef proprietor of the two-Michelin star Restaurant Sat Bains with Rooms in Nottingham.

He won the Roux Scholarship in 1999 and worked in France before returning to the UK and opening his own restaurant.

Bains was one of the winners on the BBC show Great British Menu in 2007. He has also made appearances on the BBC's Saturday Kitchen, UKTV's Market Kitchen and the 2012 series Mind of a Chef with David Chang.

Dave Brailsford

Sir Dave Brailsford CBE who was born in Shardlow is a prominent figure in British cycling.

He was performance director of British Cycling from 2003 to 2014 during which time Great Britain led the cycling medal table at the 2008 and 2012 Olympic Games, winning eight golds at both.

British cyclists also won 59 World Championships across different disciplines from 2003 to 2013.

Brailsford has since been general manager of British professional outfit Team Sky which is now known as Team Ineos.

Paul Burrell

The Grassmoor-born TV personality and writer was originally a servant in the British Royal Household who rose to prominence due to his role as butler to Diana, Princess of Wales.

Since her death in 1997, Burrell has featured strongly in the media due to this connection. Following the publication of his 2003 memoirs ‘A Royal Duty’ Princes William and Harry accused Burrell of betraying their mother's confidence, calling the book "a cold and overt betrayal."

Burrell has appeared in a range of shows including I’m a Celebrity, Through the Keyhole and In Therapy.

Jo Caulfield

Actress, writer and comedian Jo Caulfield was brought up in Derbyshire before moving to London in her late teens.

In addition to being a regular on the stand-up circuit and at the Edinburgh Festival Caulfield has written for many well-known names including Ruby Wax and Graham Norton.

Her TV career has included appearances on Never Mind The Buzzcocks, Mock the Week, The Stand-up Show, The Comedy Store, Have I Got News For You and Michael McIntyre's Comedy Roadshow.

Tom Chambers

Darley Dale born actor Tom Chambers was educated at Repton School.

He is perhaps best known for his role as Sam Strachan in the BBC medical dramas Holby City and Casualty.

He also played Max Tyler in BBC drama series Waterloo Road before portraying Inspector Sullivan in BBC's Father Brown.

More recently he has appeared in Emmerdale and Midsomer Murders and returned to musical theatre in a production of Crazy for You.

Chambers won the sixth series of Strictly Come Dancing with partner Camilla Dallerup.

Timothy Dalton

The fourth James Bond moved to Belper aged four where he attended the Herbert Strutt Grammar School.

Dalton portrayed 007 in The Living Daylights (1987) and Licence to Kill (1989) - the fifteenth and sixteenth Bond movies. Dalton's portrayal of Bond was darker and more serious than his predecessor Roger Moore.

Dalton has also appeared in the films Flash Gordon (1980), The Rocketeer (1991), Looney Tunes: Back in Action (2003), Hot Fuzz (2007), and The Tourist (2010).

On TV he has played Mr Rochester in Jane Eyre (1983), Rhett Butler in Scarlett (1994), Rassilon in Doctor Who (2009–2010), Sir Malcolm Murray on Penny Dreadful (2014–2016), and since 2019 the Chief on Doom Patrol.

Dalton’s partners include reporter Kate Adie, actress Vanessa Redgrave and Russian singer-songwriter Oksana Grigorieva.

Patricia Greene

Patricia ‘Paddy’ Greene MBE is a 90-year-old actor. She was born in Allenton and worked as an orderly at Derbyshire Children’s Hospital prior to attending drama school in London.

Her lengthy career in radio and film has been dominated by her portrayal of matriarch Jill Archer in BBC Radio 4 soap The Archers since 1957 - which makes her the world's longest serving soap opera actor.

Greene was awarded an honorary MA by Derby University in 2017.

Simon Groom

Broadcaster and presenter Simon Groom was born in Chesterfield and educated at Belper’s Herbert Strutt Grammar School.

He rose to prominence in 1978 when he began a eight-year stint as one of the presenters on BBC TV’s flagship children’s programme Blue Peter.

Since then Groom has worked as a radio presenter and a producer of TV documentaries including a biopic of film director Ken Russell, The Story of the Flying Scotsman for Channel 4 and Full Circle: the Saving of Derby's Roundhouse' for the BBC.

Rosamund Hanson

Clothes designer Daniel Hanson’s actress daughter was born in Derby.

Her first major film role came in 2005 when she starred in This is England which picked up a number of awards across the globe.

Following the success of the film Hanson went on to reprise her character Smell in the hit TV series This is England 86, 88 and 90.

She has also appeared in Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant's sitcom Life's too Short.

Leon Haslam

The Derbyshire-based motorcycle road racer now rides for Honda in the World Superbike Championship.

Nicknamed ‘Pocket Rocket’ Haslam is the son of former road-racer 'Rocket Ron' Haslam.

He has raced on either the British or World Superbike circuit since the early part of the 21st century for a wide range of teams including Ducati, Suzuki, BMW, Honda and Aprilia.

In 2018 Haslam won 15 of the 26 British Superbike for Kawasaki to complete the season as champion.

Robert Lindsay

Ilkeston-born Lindsay is an instantly recognisable English stage and TV actor.

After appearing in Get Some In, his first major TV role was playing Wolfie Smith in 1970’s BBC sitcom Citizen Smith.

He then went on to play the role of Ben Harper in My Family for over a decade while his film appearances include Fierce Creatures and Wimbledon plus two appearances as Tony Blair.

He has also regularly appeared with the Royal Shakespeare Company and in musical theatre and has won a BAFTA, a Tony and two Oliviers for his work.

The actor is a lifelong Derby County fan and his voice is heard on the popular ‘Steve Bloomer’s Watchin’ anthem which is played on matchdays at Pride Park.

Duncan Lloyd

Derby-born Duncan Lloyd is the lead songwriter and backing vocalist for Maxïmo Park whose seventh album, Nature Always Wins, this year reached No.2 in the U.K. Charts.

He also works as a solo artist, under the name Decade in Exile and as a member of Res Band and alternative rock band Nano Kino.

Alongside song-writing Lloyd is an exhibiting painter and photographer.

John Lowe

Three-time darts world champion John Lowe originates from the village of New Tupton and now lives in Chesterfield.

Along with Eric Bristow and Jocky Wilson he dominated his sport during the 1980s, claiming the prestigious World Championship in 1979, 1987 and 1993.

In total, Lowe won 15 BDO and WDF majors and held the World No. 1 ranking on four occasions.

In October 1984 ‘Old Stoneface,’ as Lowe was nicknamed, became the first player to hit a televised nine-dart finish.

Ellen MacArthur

Dame Ellen MacArthur DBE is from the village of Whatstandwell, near Matlock.

MacArthur was a highly successful solo long-distance yachtswoman. Since retirement she has gone on to achieve huge amounts for a number of charitable causes.

On February 7 2005 she broke the world record for the fastest solo circumnavigation of the globe. MacArthur sailed her trimaran Castorama 27,354 nautical miles (50,660 km) in 71 days, 14 hours, 18 minutes and 33 seconds.

Following her retirement from professional sailing in 2010 MacArthur launched the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with business and education.

Hilary Mantel

Dame Hilary Mantel DBE, who originates from Glossop, is a British writer whose work includes historical fiction, personal memoirs and short stories.

Her 2009 novel Wolf Hall, a fictional account of Thomas Cromwell's rise to power in the court of Henry VIII, won that year's Booker Prize.

The sequel to Wolf Hall, Bring Up the Bodies, won the 2012 Costa Book of the Year and her second Booker Prize – making her the first British writer and the first woman to win the Booker Prize more than once.

The books were adapted into plays by the Royal Shakespeare Company and were produced as a mini-series by BBC.

The third novel of the Thomas Cromwell trilogy, called The Mirror and the Light, was selected for the 13-strong longlist for the 2020 Booker Prize.

Mantel was made a CBE in 2006 and a Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire (DBE) in 2014.

Jack O'Connell

The actor, who was born in Alvaston, is the grandson of Ken Gutteridge who played for and was previously manager at Burton Albion FC.

His 2006 film debut as a teenage skinhead in the drama This Is England was the first of a number of roles which required him to play an angry, troubled youth.

He later found fame as James Cook on the E4 teen comedy-drama series Skins which was followed by lead roles in the film Eden Lake (2009) and TV dramas Dive (2010) and United (2011).

O'Connell gave critically acclaimed performances in independent films Starred Up (2013) and '71 (2014) and subsequently starred as war hero Louis Zamperini in the 2014 war film Unbroken for which he received the BAFTA Rising Star Award.

He has since starred in the thriller Money Monster (2016) and the Netflix western limited series Godless (2017).

William Roche

The 89-year-old actor was brought up in Ilkeston before spending three years in the British Army.

After four years as a stage actor and in minor TV roles Roche landed the part of Ken Barlow in the ITV soap opera Coronation Street when it launched in December 1960.

He has played the part continuously ever since, and as a result is listed in the Guinness World Records as the longest-serving male television star in a continuous role.

In 1999, he was awarded the British Soap Awards Lifetime Achievement Award before being awarded an MBE in 2001.

Michael Socha

The Littleover-born actor, who attended St Benedict School, in Darley Abbey, is the older brother of actress Lauren Socha, star of the Channel 4 comedy-drama Misfits.

Socha, whose credits include a wide range of TV and film roles, is best known for the film This Is England and subsequent TV series This Is England '86, '88 and '90.

Other notable performances include Summer, Being Human, Once Upon a Time in Wonderland and BBC Three’s Our World War.

Jason Statham

The Shirebrook-born film star has a varied back-story having initially risen to prominence as a top-class diver who competed for England at the 1990 Commonwealth Games.

He then modelled for the likes of Tommy Hilfiger, Griffin, and Levi before landing small parts in Guy Ritchie crime films Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels and Snatch.

Since then, Statham has been a staple in heist and action thriller movies including the Transporter trilogy, the Italian Job (2003), Crank (2006), War (2007), The Bank Job (2008), The Mechanic (2011) and Spy (2015).

He has found further success as part of the ensemble action series The Expendables (2010–14) and the Fast & Furious franchise.

Gwen Taylor

Actress Gwen Taylor was born in the village of Crich.

She is known for her roles in a range of well-known TV shows and in particular sitcoms including Duty Free (1984–1986) and Barbara (1999–2003).

She also played Peggy Armstrong in ITV drama series Heartbeat from 2005 to 2009, Anne Foster in soap opera Coronation Street (2011–2012) and is currently seen as Violet Highway in BBC’s EastEnders.

She was nominated for the 1990 Best Actress BAFTA for her role as Rita Simcock in the comedy series A Bit of a Do.

Her film appearances include Monty Python's Life of Brian (1979) and The Lady in the Van (2015).

Sarah Rhiannon Ward

The Peak District novelist who writes crime fiction series as Sarah Ward has also this year written Gothic thriller The Quickening under the name Rhiannon Ward.

A follow-up to this, The Shadowing, is due to be published in September.

Her series of four crime novels – In Bitter Chill (2015), A Deadly Thaw (2017), A Patient Fury and The Shrouded Path (2019) – feature female detective Connie Childs.

The books are set in and near the fictional town of Bampton, which the author describes as a hybrid of Buxton and Cromford.

Vivienne Westwood

The fashion icon was born in the village of Tintwhistle on the Derbyshire-Cheshire border.

Dame Vivienne Westwood DBE is considered largely responsible for bringing modern punk and new wave fashions into the mainstream.

She rose to prominence when she made clothes for Sex Pistols’ manager Malcolm McLaren's boutique in the King's Road.

Westwood went on to open four shops in London and eventually expanded throughout the United Kingdom and around the world, selling an increasingly varied range of merchandise.

Her designs are renowned for promoting political causes such as the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament, climate change and civil rights groups.

Notable clients have included Richard Branson – for whom she designed Virgin Atlantic uniforms – and Princess Eugenie who wore Westwood designs for the pre-wedding dinner, wedding ceremony and after-wedding party at the wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton.

Westwood was awarded an OBE in 1992 which was upgraded to a DBE in 2006.
